title: 108_hr1595
content: COOPERATION AND SUPPORT FOR DESIGNATED GATEWAY COMMUNITIES. The "Healthy Public Lands, Healthy Communities Act" allows the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to provide technical assistance and cooperation to designated gateway communities for mutual benefit in resource protection and community development. This includes assigning agency employees to work with communities on land use or management plans. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture may offer training sessions for designated gateway communities' officials to better understand agency planning processes and how to participate in the development of agency plans and policies. This includes information on how local governments can become cooperating agencies under the National Environmental Policy Act. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture may enter into cooperative agreements with designated gateway communities to coordinate land use activities for Federal lands, community lands, and potentially other Federal agencies. Interagency cooperation and coordination among Federal agencies, State, local, and tribal governments near Federal lands is encouraged. Federal land management agencies may consolidate plans impacting gateway communities. Up to $1,000,000 can be appropriated annually for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations not exceeding $1,000,000 annually for grants to designated gateway communities by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture. Criteria for grant awards will be jointly developed. A designated gateway community includes various subdivisions of a State, federally recognized Indian tribes, or Alaska Native villages. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for a federally recognized Indian tribe or Alaska Native village to be significantly affected by planning decisions regarding Federal lands and enter into a cooperative agreement with the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture.
